author: By Richard C. Paddock and Thomas Cristofoletti
title: At Angkor Wat, ‘You Have One of the World’s Wonders to Yourself’
description: Cambodia has been open to foreign tourists for months, but in this time of Covid, few have made the trip, making it possible to imagine that you alone have rediscovered the glorious temple complex.
content: ANGKOR WAT, Cambodia — Standing shoulder to shoulder, jostling for the perfect angle, hordes of tourists used to gather before dawn each morning to watch the sun rise over the magnificent ancient temple of Angkor Wat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Kittch Is a New Culinary Livestreaming Platform
description: The website allows chefs and others to make money from cooking classes, selling goods and more.
content: A new, food-centric livestreaming platform with a grab bag of cooking classes, kitchen tours, interviews, market visits and brand introductions, went live last week. Called Kittch, it has already developed a roster of chefs and personalities like Amanda Freitag, Elena Arzak, Ruth Reichl, Marc Vetri and Marcus Samuelsson. Chefs and others can make money by charging for cooking classes, selling merchandise and so forth; there is a mix of free and paid content for viewers. It’s also a month that will feature women in the hospitality industry for International Women’s History Month, with Elizabeth Blau, a chef and consultant, curating the content. The company was created by Brian T. Bedol, who founded Classic Sports Network and more; Elana Karp, a founder of Plated; and Douglas DeLuca, a producer of Jimmy Kimmel Live. Until March 31, for every new registration, a donation will be made to the Women’s Hospitality Initiative and MAPP (Mentorship, Advocacy, Pandemic Relief and Powder of Women).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil and Annie Karni
title: At least four House Democrats test positive after a party retreat, but it’s difficult to know where they were infected.
description: All four House members attributed their lack of severe symptoms to protection from vaccines.
content: At least four House Democrats in quick succession have said that they tested positive for the coronavirus after a party retreat held last week in Philadelphia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Read Halle Berry’s speech accepting the #SeeHer Award for boundary-pushing.
description: She said she once aspired to roles played by white men. Now she wants parts that reflect “the reality of my journey, in all of its beauty and all of its pain.”
content: On Sunday evening, Halle Berry accepted the Critics Choice Association’s #SeeHer Award, which honors a woman who pushes “boundaries on changing stereotypes” and furthers “authentic portrayals of women across the entertainment landscape.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Parents: Will You Vaccinate Your Young Kids?
description: We want to hear more about how parents are making decisions to vaccinate themselves and their children.
content: The pandemic has been a difficult time for families, full of complicated decisions. We are exploring why some families are choosing to vaccinate while others are not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Weiner
title: N.C.A.A. Women’s Bracket: Double-Digit Seeds Could Be the Ones to Watch
description: All four of the top teams — Stanford, South Carolina, North Carolina State and Louisville — look vulnerable this year.
content: The top seeds fell into place as predicted. Stanford, the reigning champions; South Carolina, North Carolina State and Louisville garnered the top four seeds in the 2022 women’s Division I tournament — but that doesn’t make it any easier to follow the chalk when filling out your own bracket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Kyiv’s Once-Busy Streets Empty as Russia Targets Capital
description: With civilian areas coming under fire and an estimated half the population having fled, the avenues of the Ukrainian capital, under siege by Russian forces, are almost deserted.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — The Ukrainian capital feels almost empty, its wide avenues mostly deserted except for soldiers at sandbagged checkpoints on the main intersections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Phoenix Rising’ and ‘Welcome to Flatch’
description: A two-part documentary about Evan Rachel Wood’s activism around domestic violence debuts on HBO. And a new comedy series begins on Fox.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, March 14-20. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Jeanna Smialek
title: Manchin won’t support Raskin for the Fed, imperiling her nomination.
description: Republicans had already opposed Sarah Bloom Raskin as the Federal Reserve’s top bank cop.
content: Senator Joe Manchin III, a key centrist Democrat, announced on Monday that he would not support Sarah Bloom Raskin for a top position on the Federal Reserve, potentially dooming her chances for confirmation as Republicans show little appetite for placing a supporter of stricter bank regulation into the powerful role.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: A Conductor on Why He Stayed in Russia After the Invasion Began
description: The Estonian American conductor Paavo Järvi chose to remain in Moscow temporarily to lead a Russian youth orchestra: “I felt a responsibility.”
content: As the Russian military began its attack on Ukraine in late February, the Estonian American conductor Paavo Järvi was in Moscow, leading rehearsals for a long-planned engagement with a Russian youth orchestra.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gisela Williams and Angela Simi
title: In the German Countryside, a Farmhouse Turned Lush Cultural Retreat
description: On the grounds of a former agricultural collective an hour north of Berlin, the artist Danh Vo has built a commune for like-minded talents.
content: AT THE HEART of Danh Vo’s farmhouse in Brandenburg, Germany, is an oven. Not just any oven, though. This wood-burning clay furnace, the size of a Volkswagen minibus, painted a dark azure and bisecting the large living area, was one of the few things Vo knew he had to have in the house: a modern version of a traditional Russian stove, which was used for both cooking and heating. Once, these impressive pieces of masonry were the locus of the home and the inspiration for several Russian fairy tales. Many had large shelves or flat-roofed extensions, reached by small ladders and topped with mattresses. Vo’s has a platform that juts out in the rear, radiating heat, with room to seat four.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: There Are Almost Too Many Things to Worry About
description: They range from tragedy to farce, with no end in sight.
content: Bret Stephens: Last week I joined a video call with the estimable Russia expert Fiona Hill to discuss the war in Ukraine. She warned that Vladimir Putin may already be laying the groundwork for the use of chemical or even tactical nuclear weapons should he fail to win quickly, perhaps through some “false flag” operation that he can blame on Ukraine or the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Peak Strawberry Season Arrives a Little Early in New York
description: Bowery Strawberries, from Bowery Farming in Kearny, N.J., offers ripe, flavorful berries that are free of pesticides.
content: If you’re as fussy about strawberries as I am, you know that they’re one of the most pesticide-laden fruits in the market. You haven’t really tasted their full flavor until you’ve tried locally grown varieties, which are a world away from the underripe fruit picked for shipping. Now there’s a new option on the local front, so New Yorkers won’t have to wait until late May. Bowery Farming, which, despite its name, grows greens in a giant indoor facility in Kearny, N.J., has just introduced Bowery Strawberries, two varieties packed together in 4-ounce containers. They’re free of pesticides, ripe and only available for a limited time. The berries labeled Garden are juicy and pretty, with decent flavor but not much aroma. The type called Wild look about the same as the Garden ones, but they are winners with a lovely perfume and a bright, tart sweetness. It should be noted that the farm labels the fruit “wild” even though they have nothing to do with the tiny berries generally known as fraises des bois, or wild strawberries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Powell Admires Paul Volcker. He May Have to Act Like Him.
description: The Federal Reserve is facing the fastest inflation most Americans have ever seen. Its chair says policymakers will do what it takes to tame prices.
content: To Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, Paul Volcker is more than a predecessor. He is one of his professional heroes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: After a Showdown, Juilliard’s President Retains Support of Board
description: The school’s chairman and biggest benefactor, Bruce Kovner, had wanted its president, Damian Woetzel, to leave after a negative evaluation. He marshaled support and stayed.
content: When the charismatic former New York City Ballet star Damian Woetzel was named president of the prestigious Juilliard School in 2017, the school’s powerful chairman, Bruce Kovner, praised his “unusual mix” of intellectual and artistic qualities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Iowa Wins Big Ten Title, Hoping Its Season Is a Harbinger of Larger Success
description: With candidates for the Naismith Award and nine teams headed to the N.C.A.A. tournament, the league hopes for a better showing than last year’s.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — The Iowa fans at Gainbridge Fieldhouse here on Sunday might have assumed the ball would go through the net as soon as the Hawkeyes star sophomore Keegan Murray released it from beyond the 3-point arc.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Jo Becker
title: Ginni Thomas Says She Attended Jan. 6 Rally
description: The disclosure by the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas is likely to raise new questions about her support of efforts to overturn the 2020 election results.
content: Ginni Thomas, the wife of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas, said in an interview published on Monday that she attended the Jan. 6, 2021, rally at the Ellipse in Washington. The interview appeared in The Washington Free Beacon, a conservative publication, and followed a New York Times Magazine article last month that examined the political and personal history of both Ms. Thomas and her husband, including her role in efforts to overturn the presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Maria Bakalova, Billy Crystal and other stars show support for Ukraine.
description: Most of the Critics Choice ceremony has been focused on prizes, but the war in Ukraine has been addressed in a few ways.
content: Most of the Critics Choice ceremony has been focused on prizes, but the war in Ukraine has been addressed in a few ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: idiosyncrasy
description: This word has appeared in 12 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word idiosyncrasy has appeared in 12 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 27 in the guest essay “Why Space Tourists Won’t Find the Awe They Seek” by Henry Wismayer:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Monika Pronczuk
title: Two Refugees, Both on Poland’s Border. But Worlds Apart.
description: A young man fleeing war in Sudan and a young woman evacuating Ukraine crossed into Poland at the same time. They had very different experiences.
content: KUZNICA, Poland — On the day war broke out in Ukraine, Albagir, a 22-year-old refugee from Sudan, was lying on the frozen forest floor at the gateway to Poland, trying to stay alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña and David E. Sanger
title: The U.S. warns China not to give Russia military or economic aid.
description: The Kremlin denied the report, and the spokesman for the Chinese Embassy in Washington said he had never heard of the request.
content: President Biden’s national security adviser met with a top Chinese official on Monday to warn against China giving Russia military or economic assistance, as the Kremlin struggles with the aftermath of its invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naz Deravian
title: For Afghans Abroad, Nowruz Is a Chance to Reflect
description: The holiday marks the beginning of spring, with many in the diaspora celebrating with rebirth, renewal and, now, resistance in mind.
content: Durkhanai Ayubi laughed as she recalled peeling walnuts as a child for haft mewa, a beloved Nowruz dish of her native Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Hong Kong lacks the resources for a China-style pandemic response, the city’s leader says.
description: “Hong Kong is very different from many mainland cities and therefore we cannot have any comparison,” Mrs. Lam told reporters at a news conference.
content: Hong Kong is struggling to get a handle on its worst coronavirus outbreak since the start of the pandemic, warning that it doesn’t have the testing capacity to carry out the strict strategy handed down by Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: How Have You Noticed Inflation?
description: Which products and services important to you have gotten more expensive?
content: Note: This Student Opinion prompt accompanies our Jan. 24 lesson plan on inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James B. Stewart
title: Bill Gross Ruled the Bond World for Years. Then He Was Deposed.
description: In “The Bond King,” Mary Childs traces the rise and fall of the superstar fund manager.
content: THE BOND KINGHow One Man Made a Market, Built an Empire, and Lost It AllBy Mary Childs
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: How High Oil Prices Threaten a California Plastic Container Business
description: Rising energy costs are lifting the prices of key materials and intensifying inflation, compounding supply chain disruptions caused by the pandemic.
content: Long before President Vladimir V. Putin unleashed his war on Ukraine, Mosharraf Khalid was already contending with an expensive, bewildering and unrelenting assortment of problems afflicting the global supply chain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Yankees Remake Infield by Trading Gary Sánchez
description: An All-Star catcher who had fallen on hard times, Sánchez is headed to Minnesota with Gio Urshela in a trade for Josh Donaldson, Isiah Kiner-Falefa and a young catcher.
content: It started with a bang, and had plenty of ups (and quite a few downs), but the Gary Sánchez era in New York ended on Sunday when the Yankees traded the two-time All-Star catcher to the Minnesota Twins.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: 81 People Are Executed in Saudi Arabia
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 14, 2022.
content: “The world should know by now that when Mohammed bin Salman promises reform, bloodshed is bound to follow.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: Broadway Singing Coach, 87, Has Brain Injury After Street Attack
description: Barbara Maier Gustern was pushed to the ground outside her Manhattan apartment building by a woman who remains at large.
content: A highly regarded 87-year-old singing coach has a traumatic brain injury after a woman pushed her to the ground just steps away from her Manhattan apartment building on Thursday night, the police and relatives said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: How Not to Have a Putin Recession
description: The Fed should keep calm and carry on.
content: Kevin McCarthy, the Republican House minority leader, said something cynical and transparently dishonest the other day. To be fair, that’s sort of an evergreen remark; you could have said the same thing about him just about any week over the past few years. But this particular statement seemed important, because it involved a lie that has a direct bearing on how America will respond to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: N.Y.P.D. Rolls Out New Version of Anti-Gun Unit With Violent Past
description: Officers will wear modified uniforms, not plain clothes, in the unit, which in its previous form was involved in a disproportionate number of fatal shootings.
content: A revamped version of a specialized police unit focused on getting firearms off New York’s streets began operating on Monday in line with one of Mayor Eric Adams’s central campaign pledges as gun violence in the city remains above its prepandemic levels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Jordan
title: Serial Killers, Bank Robbers and H.M.S. Bounty Mutineers
description: Three new true-crime books traipse through murder and mayhem around the globe.
content: HELL’S HALF-ACRE
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: British government announces plan to allow residents to sponsor refugees.
description: The program, called “Homes for Ukraine,” offers a new route for Ukrainian refugees to come to Britain, which had previously been limited to those joining family members already living there.
content: LONDON — As the humanitarian toll in Ukraine intensifies, the British government announced on Monday a program  for British residents to sponsor Ukrainian refugees,  amid widespread criticism of the country’s limited pathways for those fleeing the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Thomas Demakos, Judge in Howard Beach Murder Case, Dies at 98
description: In a notorious 1987 trial over the death of a Black man in New York City, he ruled that defense lawyers could not exclude potential jurors on the basis of race.
content: Thomas A. Demakos, the New York State Supreme Court justice who delivered a landmark ruling that lawyers for three white defendants could not automatically exclude Black people from the jury in a notorious, racially-motivated murder case in the Howard Beach section of Queens in 1987, died on Feb. 22 at his home in Queens. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Rain, Wind, Cold, Tornado Warnings and After Five Days, a Champion
description: The Players Championship was battered by some of the worst weather PGA Tour pros had ever seen. Eventually, Cameron Smith of Australia prevailed.
content: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — There was an early omen that this year’s Players Championship, a signature event of the PGA Tour, would radically defy golf tournament convention. It arrived before the sun rose for Thursday’s first round in the form of an ominous-sounding weather delay, delivered as the golfers slept.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and David E. Sanger
title: Diplomacy Quickens to Halt Ukraine War or Stop Its Expansion
description: Ukraine and Russia held a new round of talks and agreed to resume them on Tuesday, as the United States warned China about helping an increasingly isolated Kremlin and expanding the conflict.
content: LONDON — Diplomatic activity quickened on multiple fronts Monday as Russia’s war on Ukraine entered an uncertain new phase, with President Vladimir V. Putin’s forces widening their bombardment of Kyiv and other cities, hundreds of civilians escaping the devastated port of Mariupol, and the United States warning China over its deepening alignment with an isolated Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gardner
title: Feeling Forgotten as Baseball Gets Back to Business
description: Aaron Pointer, the last professional to hit .400, is part of a group of retirees that has had to fight for even a minimal pension.
content: Every spring for the past several years, Aaron Pointer has climbed his steep driveway, taken a short stroll down the street and opened his mailbox to find a letter from Major League Baseball. Each time, as he walks back to his home, with the Tacoma Narrows Bridge peeking out over the water, he reflects on the long struggle for this small recognition. And then he tears into the envelope, revealing a check for about $900 and a letter explaining how this payment is not guaranteed to continue next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jean H. Lee
title: Kim Jong-un Is Just Getting Started
description: You could be forgiven for forgetting about North Korea, which went quiet for a stretch. Now there’s been a burst of missile tests in the new year.
content: You could be forgiven for forgetting about North Korea, which went quiet for a stretch, locked in self-imposed isolation for two years during the pandemic while U.S. attention diverted to other crises (like the perilous fate of Ukraine).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: It’s Possible to Learn the Right Thing From the Wrong Person
description: We do human wisdom a great disservice when we expect it to be perfectly embodied in a flawed human being.
content: In 1980, my senior year of high school, I sat in an auditorium watching “A Man for All Seasons.” The film, based on Robert Bolt’s play of the same title, won the 1967 Academy Award for best picture, as well as five other Oscars. It was also one of the formative artistic experiences of my life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Fox News correspondent Benjamin Hall has been injured in Ukraine.
description: Mr. Hall is a longtime war correspondent who joined the network in 2015.
content: The Fox News correspondent Benjamin Hall was injured on Monday in Ukraine while reporting outside Kyiv and has been hospitalized, the network said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Need a Haircut? Pay What You Wish at This Barbershop
description: Fellow Barber in Brooklyn has expanded its experiment in affordable haircuts provided by junior barbers.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. You did remember to set your clock ahead, didn’t you? Today we’ll look at what happens when customers can pay what they can. We’ll also look at how New York’s State Capitol, dormant during the pandemic, is coming back to life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Should Russian Athletes Be Barred From Competition?
description: Our columnist examines whether the soft power of sport should be wielded against Russia, penalizing athletes with little or no say in its actions.
content: Russia’s Daniil Medvedev, the top-ranked male tennis player in the world, is the No. 1 seed at the big Indian Wells tournament set to finish this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Gatrell
title: Europe, the ‘Dark Continent,’ Is the Stage for Another Great Migration
description: Can it rise to the challenge?
content: Another great migration is underway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: How Will It End?
description: The next two or three weeks may decide whether Ukraine can survive as a state.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Foxconn, which assembles Apple’s iPhones, suspends production at factories in Shenzhen, China, because of a lockdown.
description: The Taiwanese electronics firm said it “adjusted the production line” to other plants in China to minimize any impact on operations.
content: Foxconn, the Taiwanese electronics firm that assembles Apple’s iPhones, said Monday that its factories in Shenzhen, China, would suspend operations after the city imposed a seven-day coronavirus lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanya Yanagihara
title: An Artist’s House Is Never Just a House
description: T Magazine’s spring Design issue explores homes where creative work gets done, from a former agricultural commune near Berlin to a vibrant Modernist fantasy in Los Angeles.
content: For an artist, home is not just a shelter. It’s a studio, a refuge, a cabinet of secrets, a site of inspiration. It’s where work gets done — work that will someday be released into the world but also, just as crucially, work that will end up in the trash, literally or figuratively. Home is a place to experiment, to make mistakes, to be vulnerable. Home is a place where you never have to defend your creations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: A New York City Childhood Leads to Anxiety and Jokes in ‘What’s So Funny?’
description: David Sipress, a cartoonist who regularly contributes to The New Yorker, remembers growing up in a city simultaneously grimier and more glamorous.
content: I almost didn’t read “What’s So Funny? A Cartoonist’s Memoir,” by David Sipress, because the shadow of the cartoonist Roz Chast’s pretty-much-perfect memoir “Can’t We Talk About Something More Pleasant?” (2014) loomed so largely — you might even say cartoonishly — over it. This would have been a terrible mistake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: Comedy Undercut ‘The Life.’ Billy Porter Looks for Its Humanity.
description: The actor is directing an Encores! revival of the 1997 musical, updating it to confront hard truths about racism, poverty and carceral injustice.
content: When “The Life” opened on Broadway in 1997, the sex trade in Times Square that it depicts was no longer a prominent feature of the area. Like an increasingly polished Midtown Manhattan, the musical, about the women and men who once made it a prostitution capital, was sufficiently family-friendly for my parents to take me to see it, at the age of 15, as my first Broadway show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $925,000 Homes in California
description: An Edwardian home in Sacramento, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1972 ranch house in Davis.
content: This property is less than half a mile from the original California Governor’s Mansion, an Italianate house built in the late 1870s. It is less than two miles from the State Capitol and a short walk from downtown Sacramento. Like many houses in this part of the city, it dates to the early 20th century and retains its original facade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandeep Ravindran
title: Here Come the Artificial Intelligence Nutritionists
description: Companies are experimenting with personalized diet apps, saying the future of healthy eating is A.I.
content: After 20 years of living with Type 2 diabetes, Tom Idema had given up hope of controlling his condition. He had tried many diets that proved unsuccessful and even considered weight loss surgery. When his employer offered him a chance to try a new dietary app that uses artificial intelligence to control blood sugar, he took it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Ari Wegner: A Cinematographer Who Knows Actors Down to the Eyelash
description: The director of photography for “The Power of the Dog” spent a year on preproduction. Now she could make Oscar history as the first woman to win best cinematography.
content: LOS ANGELES — Ari Wegner discovered filmmaking as an art form — and a possible career — late in high school. “The Power of the Dog” cinematographer, who may become the first woman to ever win an Academy Award in the category, grew up in an art-filled world in Melbourne, Australia, with a father who was a painter and visual artist and a mother who was “super creative.” Art and architecture filled their home. Movies, not so much. That changed when Wegner’s media teacher showed her some shorts from renowned filmmakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A Russian assault on NATO’s doorstep.
content: Russia launched a barrage of attacks against a military base in Ukraine yesterday, bringing the war 11 miles from the border with Poland. About 1,000 foreigners who had come to help Ukraine were believed to have been training at the base. “The entire sky was in flames,” one witness said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: School Inequality Isn’t Always Just Black and White
description: We care too much about the racial demographics at exclusive schools.
content: In the previous edition of this newsletter, I wrote about the city of Piedmont, Calif., and its attempt to integrate its school district through a transfer program that would take students from neighboring Oakland, a predominantly Black and Latino city. This plan, unsurprisingly, was met with a great deal of resistance but not from whom you might expect. For the most part, the population of Piedmont, where the average house price runs over $3 million, was fine with the plan, especially given that it would help boost its declining school enrollment numbers. (In California, state funding for public schools is pegged to enrollment and attendance figures.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tell Us About Your Return to Work Plans
description: How is your company trying to get you to stop working from home?
content: As Covid cases fall, companies are trying once more to bring employees back to the office. Some, like the Times, are dangling incentives like free pizza. Others are using more forceful nudges to dis-incentivize working from home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Bin Bin Sake Brings a Large Selection to Greenpoint
description: The store stocks sakes from Japanese and local producers, along with Japanese whiskies, shōchūs and wine.
content: Since 2007, when Sakaya opened in the East Village, followed much more recently by Kuraichi in Industry City in Brooklyn, the city has made do with only a few sake boutiques. It now has some competition. Bin Bin Sake from Sunday Hospitality and the sake sensei George Padilla stocks sakes from Japanese and local producers, along with Japanese whiskies, shōchūs and some Japanese wines. It occupies a small corner of the space in an industrial building that’s also home to the company’s 100-seat Japanese restaurant, Rule of Thirds. Tastings, classes and subscriptions are planned. When the weather is bearable, there will be a patio for imbibing purchases (with a corkage fee).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: Lithuania, a Vulnerable NATO Link, Readies for Putin
description: The Baltics, wedged between Russia and Belarus, have been likened to a modern-day West Berlin. Many here worry that if Ukraine falls, they might be next.
content: LAZDIJAI, Lithuania — At a border crossing with Poland, Ramunas Serpatauskas was waving down cars crammed with bags, blankets and often three generations of family members one recent evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia Bombards Kyiv
description: Plus China’s effort to contain its biggest coronavirus outbreak since Wuhan.
content: Russia launched a flurry of artillery strikes on the Ukrainian capital, Kyiv, as its invasion headed into a third week. The attacks followed days of fighting in the suburbs of the city, and the Kremlin has insisted that “all plans” for the invasion will be fulfilled. Follow our live updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: How an Electric Truck Factory Became a Lightning Rod in Georgia
description: The governor hailed the factory as an economic boon that would put Georgia at the vanguard of the green economy. Not everyone liked the idea.
content: It is billed as the largest economic development project in the history of Georgia, an electric vehicle factory that could grow to be five times as large as the Pentagon and produce as many as 400,000 emissions-free trucks a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Trinity Church Fires Conductor After Misconduct Accusation
description: The conductor, Julian Wachner, denied the allegation that he sexually assaulted a woman in 2014. The church said it had not verified the accusation, but fired him for behavior “inconsistent with our expectations.”
content: Trinity Wall Street, the powerful New York church, said on Monday that it had fired its music director after receiving an allegation of sexual misconduct against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Novel Malaria Treatment for Children Receives First Approval
description: The single-dose medication, for treatment of a particular form of malaria, is a new weapon in the war against the deadly illness.
content: Australian regulators have approved a simple drug combination as an effective cure for a form of malaria in children ages 2 to 16, opening the door to approvals in other countries and heralding a new weapon in the battle against a deadly disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: Which Coronavirus Vaccine Will Work in the Youngest Children?
description: Moderna is going head-to-head with Pfizer-BioNTech for the opportunity to vaccinate the youngest children, the only Americans still not eligible for shots.
content: WASHINGTON — Over the past 10 months, as tens of millions of children and teenagers received the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, the companies’ main rival, Moderna, sat on the sidelines, its shot limited to adults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: China’s Worst Surge Since 2020
description: Sustained outbreaks have erupted in two-thirds of the country’s provinces.
content: U.S. Covid cases, seven-day average
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Companies partly exiting Russia are under pressure to make it all or nothing.
description: Some companies have revised their plans after being pushed to make a more definitive break from the country.
content: As Western governments ratchet up their economic punishments against Russia, the corporate world has paused or pulled out of operations there. But as the list of companies quitting Russia grows by the day — and as Russia’s attacks on Ukraine escalate — differences in the degree of disconnection are spurring debate, the DealBook newsletter notes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Lauren Halsey Chosen for Met Roof Installation
description: The commission, on view from May 17 through Oct. 23, will invite visitors to explore connections to ancient Egyptian symbolism, 1960s utopian architecture and more.
content: Lauren Halsey, 34, an artist from South Central Los Angeles who often makes site-specific installations and also founded a community center, has been selected for the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s annual roof garden commission, the museum announced Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: Leading the Bohemian Life in a Gramercy Studio
description: After living in many of the city’s neighborhoods, a journalist wanted stability. She found it in a rent-stabilized place that she says she will never leave.
content: “Real estate,” Claudia Steinberg said, “in a way, it determines your life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: A Fatal Crossing on the Northern Border
description: A family from India froze to death just yards away from crossing into the United States from Canada. Desperate migrants are trying their luck on the northern border.
content: PEMBINA, N.D. — The air temperature was pushing 20 below zero and howling winds were whipping up blinding snow one morning in January when U.S. Border Patrol agents in North Dakota spotted five human forms moving through the barren borderland where America and Canada meet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Democratic Group Says Trump Is Breaking Campaign Law by Not Declaring for 2024
description: The complaint to the Federal Election Commission accuses Donald Trump of improperly using his existing political committees to advance a presidential run.
content: A Democratic super PAC said it is filing a formal complaint with the Federal Election Commission on Monday accusing Donald J. Trump of violating campaign finance law by spending political funds on a 2024 presidential bid without formally declaring himself a candidate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: An Unlikely Hero
description: We look at Volodymyr Zelensky’s rise.
content: National heroes sometimes have humble political origins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A D.I.Y. Flower Arrangement for Holiday Decorating
description: Bouquet Box, a flower delivery company, provides dozens of stems with a reusable vase, tools and instructions.
content: Flowers from this new delivery company require some assembly. The blooms, usually about four dozen colorful, well-packed stems, arrive with a reusable lightweight Lucite vase that won’t upstage the flowers, necessary tools like shears and a stem-stripper, and step-by-step instructions for producing an arrangement. You keep the tools and the expertise you gain in handling flowers. (Make note: Passover starts April 15, and Easter is April 17.) Courtney Sixx, a founder of the company, currently works for Martha Stewart; Amy Nebens, the co-founder, did previously. They sell single arrangements, starting at $149, and monthly or quarterly subscriptions, starting at $129 per delivery. The website shows the designs for each calendar period, and there is a choice of classic or more abundant deluxe arrangements. For occasions demanding a beautiful centerpiece on the near-horizon, order soon; the cutoff for delivery by April 13 is March 22.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How Californians Feel About the End of School Mask Mandates
description: The change has created new divisions in the state.
content: In March 2020, California became the first state in the nation to issue a stay-at-home order to curb the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Nook for Cheese and Salumi on the Upper West Side
description: 67Gourmet, from the owners of 67 Wine & Spirits, has a wide range of things to nibble with wine.
content: The owners of 67 Wine & Spirits on the Upper West Side — in business since 1941 and originally at 67th Street and Columbus Avenue, but since moved to 68th Street — have opened 67Gourmet. This well-stocked nook up the block mostly sells cheeses, charcuterie, condiments and crackers — stuff to nibble with wine. They’ve hired Martin Johnson, a cheesemonger who went into craft beer for a few years, to oversee the store and select the goods. Most of the salumi, pâtés and terrines come from Les Trois Petits Cochons, with more purveyors planned. For the cheeses, Mr. Johnson has shopped in many countries and offers a good variety from American dairies like Jasper Hill, St. Stephen and Cypress Grove, along with selections like Époisses from France and Taleggio from Italy. Worth discovering is Moser from Switzerland, whose fluent Cru Blanc Camembert begs for sauvignon blanc alongside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘On a Dirt Court, a Ravaged School Planted the Seeds of a Championship’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the determination and grit of a girls’ basketball team and how the young players overcame adversity and 4 a.m. practices to succeed.
content: Featured Article: “On a Dirt Court, a Ravaged School Planted the Seeds of a Championship” by Jeré Longman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Leigh Dicks
title: The Peculiar Charm of Coober Pedy, Australia’s Opal Capital
description: Scattered around town are do-it-yourself mining operations, abandoned film props and a cafe that serves both waffles and opals.
content: It could have been a Saturday night in any Australian town. Against the backdrop of a fiery sunset, a line of vehicles snaked its way into the local drive-in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Why This Hollywood Actor Stays Off Social Media (Mostly)
description: Andrew Garfield, who was in “The Social Network,” shares how the film changed his view of social media and discusses his recent projects.
content: As Facebook morphs into Meta and makes a push for immersive 3-D connection (without solving all of its existing problems), Kara Swisher takes a look back at the company’s early days — and the fictionalized telling of them — with the actor Andrew Garfield. He had his breakout role playing the Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin in the 2010 film “The Social Network.” He tells Kara, “I immediately shut my Facebook page down as soon as I read the script.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Zelensky will address Congress in a virtual speech on Wednesday.
description: The Ukrainian president’s speech will likely increase growing momentum on Capitol Hill to pressure President Biden to send fighter jets to Kyiv.
content: WASHINGTON — As Russia’s offensive in Ukraine intensifies, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine will address Congress in a virtual speech on Wednesday, Democratic leaders said, a move that will likely increase growing momentum on Capitol Hill to pressure President Biden to send fighter jets to Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: A Recital Brings Together Two Schubert Masters
description: The pianist Mitsuko Uchida and the tenor Mark Padmore subtly threaded a program of Beethoven songs and Schubert’s “Schwanengesang.”
content: It’s difficult to avoid superlatives when writing about Mitsuko Uchida and Mark Padmore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Jane Campion Apologizes for Comment About Venus and Serena Williams
description: In an acceptance speech at the Critics Choice Awards, the “Power of the Dog” filmmaker wrongly suggested that the tennis greats didn’t compete against men the way she had to.
content: At the Critics Choice Awards on Sunday evening, Jane Campion won best director for her work on the revisionist western “The Power of the Dog.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: ‘Encanto’ Tops Chart for Ninth Week. Will It Be the Last?
description: The soundtrack, which includes TikTok-fueled hits like “We Don’t Talk About Bruno,” may soon be ousted by “7220,” a new release by the Chicago rapper Lil Durk.
content: This week, Disney’s “Encanto” soundtrack notches its ninth, and possibly last, time on the top of the Billboard chart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Document in Jan. 6 Case Shows Plan to Storm Government Buildings
description: New details from evidence cited in the indictment of Enrique Tarrio, the former head of the far-right Proud Boys, reveal a plan with similarities to what unfolded at the Capitol.
content: A document found by federal prosecutors in the possession of a far-right leader contained a detailed plan to surveil and storm government buildings around the Capitol on Jan. 6 last year, people familiar with the document said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: New York’s Vaccine Mandates Saved Lives, Departing Health Boss Says
description: Dr. Dave Chokshi led the city through the pandemic and is proud of its aggressive measures to combat the virus.
content: Five months into the pandemic, Dr. Dave A. Chokshi took on the greatest challenge of his career: helping to guide New York City in its fight against the coronavirus as the new health commissioner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Tristan Spinski
title: New York’s Grand Capitol Slowly Awakens From Pandemic Slumber
description: Albany’s city leaders were in the middle of an effort to revitalize its downtown when the pandemic hit and closed down the state government. Now, they are trying to bring the city back to life.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — The pace inside this hulking pile of stone was once frenetic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.K. Supreme Court Says Assange Cannot Appeal His Extradition to U.S.
description: In a blow for the embattled WikiLeaks founder, the court said it had refused permission to appeal “because the application does not raise an arguable point of law.”
content: LONDON — Britain’s Supreme Court on Monday said it had refused the latest appeal by Julian Assange, the embattled WikiLeaks founder, to prevent his extradition to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: ‘Bad Vegan’ Chronicles the Strange Story of Sarma Melngailis
description: The Netflix documentary details the New York restaurateur’s rise and fall.
content: The bizarre story of Sarma Melngailis, who ran the vegan and raw food restaurant Pure Food and Wine, has been made into a four-part documentary for Netflix. It chronicles the rise of her New York restaurant, a 2000s celebrity hangout that she opened with the chef Matthew Kenney; her allegations that her husband, Anthony Strangis, manipulated her; and her path to believing in immortality and pleading guilty to theft and fraud charges in 2017. Chris Smith, who was the executive producer of “Tiger King,” directed, and the documentary will be on Netflix starting Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: How a Murdoch Hopes to Save American Democracy
description: Kathryn Murdoch is trying to change how elections are run. It’s a work in progress.
content: Over the last decade, as America’s two dominant political parties pulled farther apart, a group of centrist-minded donors was growing increasingly frustrated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: This Year, Try Spring Cleaning Your Brain
description: Five ways to soothe a mind overstimulated by anxiety, stress and streams of information.
content: Coronavirus cases are receding across the United States, and face masks are coming off. Little green shoots are finally poking through the earth, signaling the arrival of warmer weather. The pandemic has not been declared over, but after living in survival mode for the last two years, some would say we are emerging into a “new normal.” Though that doesn’t mean our minds are at ease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Diana Nguyen, Kaitlin Roberts, Rob Szypko, Michael Simon Johnson, Marc Georges, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: How Russians See the War in Ukraine
description: As well as a military campaign, Moscow is also waging a battle over the truth.
content: Russians and Ukrainians are deeply connected. Millions of Ukrainians have relatives in Russia. Many have lived in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: Covid restrictions prevented dengue in hundreds of thousands of people in 2020.
description: A study’s findings suggest that new approaches may be needed to combat dengue and other mosquito-borne viruses.
content: Public health measures to stop the spread of Covid-19 had an unintended consequence across Latin America and Southeast Asia in 2020: Dengue virus infections were prevented in hundreds of thousands of people, according to a study published in The Lancet this month. The research offers clues for new strategies to combat a dangerous tropical disease that had been infecting more people each year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: When You’re in the N.C.A.A. Tournament, but Not Fully In
description: The low seeding of teams from historically Black universities like Texas Southern often means they must prove they belong in the field even after they’ve proved they belong.
content: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Finally, a taut game began to turn in Texas Southern’s favor. An automatic bid to the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament was within reach. An assistant coach knelt at the Texas Southern bench as if to start a decisive sprint to the finish line. Players jumped to their feet, waving towels the way trainers cool boxers between rounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: New York’s Mayor Is Building an Agenda Around Food. Will It Satisfy?
description: Eric Adams has promoted nutrition like no predecessor besides Michael Bloomberg. Some food activists see the prospect of real change, but others want more details and diligence.
content: Eric Adams wasted little time following up on his campaign promise to be a champion for all things plant-based. Just a month after taking the oath as New York City’s mayor, he announced that the city’s public schools — the largest school system in the nation — would set aside one day each week to serve only vegan meals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Are Big Businesses In or Out of Russia?
description: Companies partially pulling out of the country are under pressure to make a cleaner break.
content: As Western governments ratchet up their economic punishments against Russia after it invaded Ukraine, the corporate world has paused or pulled out of operations there. But as the list of companies quitting Russia grows by the day, differences in the degree of disconnection are spurring debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Chris Buckley
title: China Sees at Least One Winner Emerging From Ukraine War: China
description: The country’s leaders think it can shield itself from economic and diplomatic fallout and eventually be seen as a pillar of stability.
content: The war in Ukraine is far from over, but a consensus is forming in Chinese policy circles that one country stands to emerge victorious from the turmoil: China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A Quiet Winter Gives Way to a Very Loud Spring
description: With the lockout over and camps open, the Yankees remade their infield, Atlanta acquired a star (and moved on from another) and there was terrible news from the Padres.
content: The Yankees sent a tweet on Monday that only a dreamy romantic could have conjured last week amid the gloom of the Major League Baseball lockout. In a slow-motion video from the batting cage at spring training, a right-handed hitter lifted his front knee, pivoted on his back foot and whipped a bat across the plate, driving a batting practice fastball high above left field, where it disappeared in the clouds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: A protester storms a live broadcast on Russia’s most-watched news show, yelling, ‘Stop the war!’
description: The intervention by a state TV employee underscored how dissent is seeping into the public sphere in Russia, despite the Kremlin’s crackdown on anyone who challenges its official narrative of the invasion.
content: A state television employee burst onto the live broadcast of Russia’s most-watched news show on Monday evening, yelling, “Stop the war!” and holding up a sign that said, “They’re lying to you here,” in an extraordinary act of protest against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: Surge of Omicron Infections Prompts Lockdowns in China
description: After two years of largely containing coronavirus outbreaks, China’s “Covid zero” policies are being tested by the highly transmissible variant.
content: BEIJING — Several of China’s largest factory cities have ordered a lockdown, halting production of Toyota cars and Apple iPhones. Theaters, cinemas and many restaurants have closed in Shanghai. The northeastern province of Jilin on Monday banned its 24 million residents from leaving the province or traveling between cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Poland Refused to Play Russia Once. It May Have to Do So Again.
description: Poland’s stars cornered FIFA by threatening to boycott a World Cup qualifier. Now, as Russia appeals the decision, Robert Lewandowski, Wojciech Szczesny and their teammates may have to double down.
content: One by one, late on a Friday evening, Robert Lewandowski called his Poland teammates. They were scattered across Europe, and most of them were busily preparing for club games that weekend, but his question could not wait.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catalina Martínez Coral
title: The Key Argument on Abortion That Changed Everything in Colombia
description: A decade ago, few could have imagined that Latin America would become a benchmark for advances in sexual and reproductive rights.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — For decades abortion rights activists in Latin America looked to our counterparts in the global north to learn the best litigation and advocacy tools. We considered the incremental gains made in the years leading up to Roe v. Wade in the United States a blueprint for victory in our fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Dolly Parton Bows Out of Rock & Roll Hall of Fame Nomination
description: The country singer, who was among 17 genre-spanning nominees this year, said, “I don’t feel that I have earned that right” and asked to be removed. Voting has already begun.
content: Dolly Parton does not feel rock ’n’ roll enough for the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Apple iPhone SE Review: A Phone for the Anti-Consumer
description: Why spend more if you don’t have to? The new $430 iPhone meets all the criteria of what most of us need in a smartphone.
content: Apple has a new, cheaper iPhone arriving in stores on Friday that encapsulates the bare minimum of what we need in a smartphone. The latest iPhone SE has a bright screen, a zippy processor, a quality camera and robust battery life. It makes phone calls, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: Citigroup, the biggest U.S. bank in Russia, will pull out more business.
description: Citi will expand its exit, announced last April, and stop seeking new clients in Russia.
content: Citigroup, the American bank with the largest presence in Russia, said it would broaden its planned withdrawal from the country because of the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The New York Times launches a Telegram channel to deliver news about the war.
description: The channel delivers reporting from our continuous live blog, where Times journalists are providing witness accounts, interviews and breaking news from the Russia-Ukraine conflict.
content: To make our journalism more accessible to readers around the world, The New York Times has launched a new, dedicated channel on Telegram, a messaging platform with more than half a billion active users.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Democrats Want Investigation Into Postal Service’s Gas Guzzlers Contract
description: A plan to purchase up to 165,000 gasoline-powered mail trucks instead of electric models has angered Democrats and the Biden administration.
content: WASHINGTON — A group of House Democrats called Monday for an investigation into a decision by Postmaster General Louis DeJoy to purchase up to 165,000 gasoline-powered mail trucks over the Biden administration’s objections that the multibillion-dollar contract would undermine the nation’s climate goals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Pete Davidson to Join Next Blue Origin Space Flight
description: The “Saturday Night Live” comedian will be one of six passengers to fly to the edge of space this month with Blue Origin, the rocket company founded by Jeff Bezos.
content: The “Saturday Night Live” actor Pete Davidson will travel to the edge of space next week on the next Blue Origin spaceflight, the company said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: March 14, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 14, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Jacob deGrom Plans to Opt Out, but Wants to Stick Around
description: The longest-tenured Met would give up one year at $30.5 million while seeking a new contract. Pete Alonso, meanwhile, was fine after a scary car accident.
content: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Before the 2019 season, the Mets signed the ace pitcher Jacob deGrom to a five-year, $137.5 million contract extension that allowed him to opt out after the 2022 season. At the time of the deal, deGrom was coming off a dominant season in which he won his first National League Cy Young Award and finished fifth in N.L. Most Valuable Player Award voting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike
title: Idaho Is First State to Pass Abortion Ban Based on Texas’ Law
description: The bill prohibits abortions after about six weeks, and allows family members of a “preborn child” to sue abortion providers.
content: Idaho on Monday became the first state to adopt a copycat of an unusual new Texas law that relies on ordinary citizens to enforce a ban on abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy as a way of getting around court challenges to its constitutionality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: Tree Planting Is Booming. Here’s How That Could Help, or Harm, the Planet.
description: Reforestation can fight climate change, uplift communities and restore biodiversity. When done badly, though, it can speed extinctions and make nature less resilient.
content: A tree planted for every T-shirt purchased. For every bottle of wine. For every swipe of a credit card. Trees planted by countries to meet global pledges and by companies to bolster their sustainability records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Man Cave’ Review: Things That Go Bump in the American Night
description: John J. Caswell Jr.’s play is a political drama wrapped in the spooky pleasures of the horror genre.
content: Late on a thundery monsoon evening in a well-appointed basement in Sedona, Ariz., the ghosts are restless. Or something is — thumping and scratching inside the walls of a congressman’s gated home, where Imaculada, the housekeeper, has been holding down the fort alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Picking an N.C.A.A. Tournament Bracket? Read This First.
description: The N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament is filled with juicy matchups, interesting players and potential surprises.
content: The questions going into each N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament tell us about a moment in time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Here Are Three Reasons Putin Might Fight On
description: His invasion of Ukraine has been a disaster. But that doesn’t mean he’ll stop.
content: The bloody invasion of Ukraine has been a disaster for President Vladimir Putin of Russia, but that doesn’t mean he’s going to give up. There are at least three powerful ideas that could drive him onward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: A pregnant woman photographed after a Russian strike on a maternity hospital has died, The A.P. reports.
description: Her baby also died, the news organization said. The photo captured last week has become one of the defining images of human suffering in the war.
content: The image captured the suffering and chaos of the war in Ukraine in an instant: a pale pregnant woman clutching her belly as she was carried on a stretcher, the red-and-black polka dot sheet under her a stark contrast to the smoking soil, stripped trees and blasted-out maternity hospital around her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: He’s American, He Oversees Papa John’s in Russia and He’s Staying
description: Christopher Wynne’s company controls the franchise agreements for the 190 Papa John’s locations in the country. “At the end of the day, they appreciate a good pizza,” he said.
content: Papa John’s International said last week that it was suspending all of its corporate operations in Russia, following in the footsteps of other high-profile American brands like McDonald’s and Starbucks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: As Tom Brady Returns, N.F.L. Tilts Toward Its Quarterbacks
description: Tom Brady, Aaron Rodgers and Russell Wilson all made decisions that shifted plans around the league and reinforced the value of having a franchise quarterback.
content: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers’ website on Monday morning said it all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 6, Episode 8 Recap: Games Over
description: The nice guy routine served Prince well as he built New York’s bid for the Olympics. Until it didn’t.
content: “What’s the only thing worse than not getting what you want?” Chuck Rhoades asks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Man Hit Woman in the Head 125 Times Because She Was Asian, Officials Say
description: A man has been charged with attempted murder as a hate crime after a vicious assault in Yonkers, N.Y., that was captured by a security camera.
content: A 67-year-old woman, wearing a white face mask and dark hooded jacket and pushing a shopping cart, enters an apartment building vestibule in Yonkers, N.Y. As she moves to unlock the door, a man comes up behind her and hits her in the head with a roundhouse right hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Stream These 8 Great Performances by William Hurt
description: A four-time Oscar nominee, the actor played charming, explosive leading men in 1980s classics like “Children of a Lesser God” and “Broadcast News.”
content: The four-time Academy Award nominee William Hurt, who died Sunday at 71, left behind a bulging filmography — over 100 appearances in movies and television in the 45 years between his first (on a two-part episode of “Kojak”) and his last (the in-production series “Pantheon”). In between, he won an Oscar for best actor (for “Kiss of the Spider Woman,” a title that is sadly not available to stream), turned up on prestige TV and in character roles and made recurring appearances in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Here are a few of the highlights from his extensive career, and where you can stream them:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Ashley Southall
title: As Police Hunt for Gunman, Fear Rattles Homeless People in 2 Cities
description: The shootings came at a charged moment in the relationship between New York City and the thousands of people who live on the streets here.
content: Anthony Pla, homeless since 2015 and a New Yorker for 35 years, said that until this weekend, he had never experienced anything as unsettling as the streets of Manhattan emptying out during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph P. Fried
title: Bernard W. Nussbaum, Clinton Counsel and Defender, Dies at 84
description: The president’s first White House lawyer, Mr. Nussbaum had a turbulent 14 months in the job weathering a rash of controversies.
content: Bernard W. Nussbaum, who as President Bill Clinton’s first White House counsel became a lightning rod in a rash of bitter controversies that plagued Mr. Clinton early in his administration, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 2022 N.C.A.A. Women’s Tournament Bracket
description: South Carolina, N.C. State, Stanford and Louisville are the top seeds in the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament.
content: South Carolina, N.C. State, Stanford and Louisville are the top seeds in the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Palau?
description: Can you find Palau on a map? What else do you know about this island nation with 18,000 people?
content: Can you find Palau on a map? What else do you know about this island nation with 18,000 people?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Climate Change Is Killing Her Country. Who Will Decide if It Lives?
description: “The future I want,” says Tina Stege, the climate envoy for the Marshall Islands, “is a future where we get to choose.”
content: “The future I want,” says Tina Stege, the climate envoy for the Marshall Islands, “is a future where we get to choose.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $925,000 in California
description: An Edwardian home in Sacramento, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1972 ranch house in Davis.
content: An Edwardian home in Sacramento, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1972 ranch house in Davis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Pie for All Seasons
description: A week of holidays means great recipes: apple pie, saffron pistachio blondies and more.
content: Good morning. This is a week of holidays and affirmation, even as the world remains stricken by conflict and pain, offering moments in which to convene, if you’re able, and to celebrate tradition, faith — even pastry.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Getting Inside Putin’s Head: Is He Irrational?
description: Trying to figure out what makes Vladimir Putin tick. Also: China’s role; Russian war crimes; being a parent; stresses of email; don’t walk and text.
